Project Title: Digitizing vulnerable community-held archives of human rights in Colombia
Additional material types: Print (Archival), Audio, Video, Photo, Digital files
Notes on material types: The NGO has already identified boxes of material, which include  DVDs containing photographs showing individuals, public meetings educational processes, research projects, community action, memorials, and research projects. There are also documentaries on VHS, audio cassette tapes, photographs, documents on paper, (such as formal complaints of crimes against victims and relatives), documents on floppy disks, and approximately 30 videos of interviews and commemorations. The archive also comprises material inherited from the Research project Colombia Nunca Más (Colombia Never Again) particularly regarding crimes against humanity committed  in the Valle del Cauca region, dating back to 1980.

Additional material types: Bound material, Audio, Video, Video, Maps, Photo, Photo Negative, Digital files
Notes on material types: The category ''Other'' includes visual didactic materials that OMIECH refers to as ''láminas'', that is, drawings depicting scenes from everyday life in Chiapas Highland Maya communities,  mounted either on cardboard and laminated or on long rolls fabric covered in plastic. This second format allowed community workshop facilitators to hang the roll on a wall of midwives' homes where workshops are conducted. The authors of these drawings are often local Tzotzil artists and they are used to stimulate analysis and reflection on different subjects amongst participants.

Host Institution: New York University is the host institution, and our MEAP Planning Grant will be administered through NYU Sponsored Programs Administration (SPA).  NYU is the host institution for several key reasons. Zeb Tortorici is an associate professor at NYU in the Dept. of Spanish and Portuguese (and is a disciplinarily trained historian of Latin America), and has been collaborating with Archivo El Insulto for 5 years, having officially become a core member of El Insulto’s team in 2021.  Zeb has strategically and symbiotically developed his own personal digital archiving goals (based on his current monograph and digital archiving project, “Archiving the Obscene: Censorship, Erotica, and Pornography in Latin America, 1700-1955”) alongside those of Archivo El Insulto. While Archivo El Insulto has long been acquiring explicit textual and photographic records on sexuality in Mexico for its archives, Zeb has long been collecting similar records from flea markets and bookstores in Peru, Argentina, and Brazil (having already donated several records to El Insulto, with the long-term goal of donating many, if not all, of these records to Archivo El Insulto as its storage capacities and funding situation improve over time).   As part of their long-term collaboration, partnership, and exchange, both Archivo El Insulto and Zeb Tortorici have an agreement to freely share their future digitizations and digital records (including descriptive metadata) from their respective collections (i.e., Archivo El Insulto’s respective digital records from Mexico will be shared with Zeb in perpetuity, and Zeb’s respective digital records from Peru, Argentina, and Brazil, all of which date from 1900-1955, will be shared in perpetuity with Archivo El Insulto). This future digital exchange will be mutually beneficial for both Archivo El Insulto and Zeb Tortorici in terms of the development, creation, and long-term sustainability of their respective digital repositories.   For “Archiving the Obscene,” Zeb has already received ample external support (in the form of a Mellon New Directions Fellowship from 2019-2022, administered and disbursed by NYU SPA) for this research project, which has enabled him to receive yearlong graduate training and coursework in the Department of Information Studies at UCLA for the academic year 2021-22. For this project, with Mellon Foundation support, Zeb will eventually create an open-access online digital repository (entirely independent from, but strategically connected to, that of Archivo El Insulto) that will be hosted through the NYU Division of Libraries, with the long-term support of NYU’s Digital Scholarship Librarian, Librarian for Research Data Management and Reproducibility, the Research Data Management Librarian to develop and maintain his digital repository. There are several key digital storage services at NYU (including NYU Drive, NYU Box, and Research Workplace), which offer NYU faculty unlimited storage quotas at no cost. NYU has ample resources for faculty to ensure the long-term sustainability of Zeb’s future digital repository for “Archiving the Obscene.”   The many resources that NYU offers are why Archivo El Insulto, in strategic collaboration with Zeb Tortorici, chose NYU as its host institution. This partnership will contribute significantly to Archivo El Insulto’s short- and long-term goals, and to the overall success of both the MEAP Planning Grant phase of El Insulto’s project, and, in the future, the digitization phase of its records. With Zeb acting as a liaison between NYU and El Insulto, El Insulto will have the ongoing support of the NYU Division of Libraries in the key areas listed above. Conversely, Archivo El Insulto’s commitment to openly sharing its future digital files of pre-1955 records with Zeb (and hence with the NYU Division of Libraries), NYU will benefit in terms of gaining permanent rights to host and digitally display Archivo El Insulto’s digital surrogates of early twentieth-century records through Zeb’s future NYU-hosted digital repository. Thus, Archivo El Insulto, MEAP/UCLA Library, and NYU Division of Libraries all stand to benefit in the long term by this open commitment to the sharing and exchange of digital files. It is important to note that NYU digital repositories will only have access to certain records of Archivo El Insulto (specifically, those created between 1900-1955 that have direct research relevance to Zeb Tortorici’s “Archiving the Obscene: Censorship, Erotica, and Pornography in Latin America, 1700-1955” book project). Thus MEAP/UCLA Library will be the only external institution to have permanent access to all of Archivo El Insulto’s records from 1955-1990 (and MEAP will also have access to all of the pre-1955 records).  Zeb Tortorici as the PI (Principal Investigator) will oversee this MEAP Planning Grant in terms of managing the turning in of deliverables to MEAP/UCLA Library. This includes a report of the records survey, reports of the ethics workshops, records inventories, and the translation of all descriptive metadata into English for MEAP/UCLA Library. As required by NYU in order for it to be a host institution, and for NYU to disburse the majority of MEAP funds to Archivo El Insulto for use in Mexico, Zeb must take a small salary for his labors (1% of one of his summer monthly salary, plus fringe benefits for a total of $159). For this salary, which Zeb will receive as we near the end of our 12-month MEAP Planning Grant (and which Zeb will donate directly back to Archivo El Insulto), Zeb will commit to spending 4-6 weeks in Mexico in July-August of 2023, translating all of the Spanish-language descriptive metadata into English, so that it will be ready to deliver to MEAP/UCLA Library. (Please note: Zeb will use his own NYU research funds to travel to and from Mexico, and to hire a professional translator with whom to work on the English-language metadata). Ultimately, in terms of NYU serving as the host institution for the MEAP Planning Grant, Zeb Tortorici will be responsible for the management and integrity of the design, conduct, and reporting of the MEAP Planning Grant to both UCLA and to NYU. He will also be responsible for managing, monitoring, and ensuring the integrity of the collaborative relationship between Archivo El Insulto, UCLA (MEAP/UCLA Library, and NYU (liaising with NYU Sponsored Programs Administration, who will administer and disburse the grant).
